[Question]

What is your opinion on tipping, and if given the chance, how would you improve or change the current tipping system?

answer.text_box: I like the idea of tipping when you are in a restaurant. If the staff provides good service you can simply add the amount you feel is appropriate on the indicated line of the check. What I really dislike is when you are at a counter ordering coffee or some other item which requires very little skill to provide, and the cashier rings you up at the counter, merely hands over a cup of coffee, and the register indicates a 15, 20. or 25% line for tips. I would eliminate this practice for service which requires very little skill or effort.

displayed_text:
Below is a summary of people's opinions on the issue.

Overall summary of the comments:

  • General sentiment: A strong majority are dissatisfied with the current tipping culture, viewing it as overextended, coercive, and a mechanism that lets employers underpay workers. Many still tip in practice but do so reluctantly, describing tipping as an “unfortunate necessity.”

  • Wages vs. tips: Around three-quarters favor shifting pay responsibility to employers—calling for a living wage, abolishing the subminimum tipped wage, or building compensation into menu prices—so tipping becomes optional or reserved for exceptional service. A smaller group supports keeping or even strengthening tipping (e.g., higher standard rates, mandatory tips unless wages meet a threshold, or tax-free tips).

  • Where tipping is appropriate: There is broad agreement that tipping should be tied to clear, personal service (especially full-service restaurants and delivery). Many object to tips for counter service, pickup, minimal interaction, or being asked to tip before service is rendered.

  • Pressure and point-of-sale prompts: Many dislike tablet/iPad prompts and default high percentages, reporting social pressure and confusion. They want clearer “no tip” options, lower or customizable defaults, and prompts only after service.

  • Basis for tipping: Most want tipping to reflect quality of service and to remain voluntary. Several note tip fatigue, financial constraints, and confusion about norms.

  • Proposed changes and alternatives:

  • Pay a guaranteed, livable base wage (often cited as at least federal minimum or $15/hour).
  • Replace tips with a flat service charge (commonly 10%) or integrate service into prices.
  • Limit who may solicit tips (primarily full-service dining and delivery).
  • Ensure tipping occurs after service and is clearly optional.
  • Improve POS design: easy “no tip,” lower or custom suggestions, reduce pre-service prompts.
  • Other ideas raised by a minority: fixed-dollar tip norms, employer tip-matching, not taxing tips, or standardizing tip expectations.

In short, most favor reducing reliance on tips by raising wages and narrowing where tips are requested, while preserving voluntary, quality-based tipping for genuine service. A smaller share prefers maintaining or formalizing tipping with clearer standards.

Summary B

Based on the comments provided, here is an overall summary of opinions on the tipping system:

The overwhelming sentiment is that the current tipping culture has become problematic and needs significant reform. Most respondents express frustration with the expansion of tipping requests beyond traditional service settings, particularly criticizing point-of-sale systems that prompt for tips in situations where minimal or no service is provided.

Key concerns about the current system: - Tipping has expanded far beyond restaurants to include counter service, pickup orders, and basic transactions where it feels inappropriate - The pressure to tip has become uncomfortable and feels mandatory rather than voluntary - Workers are underpaid and forced to rely on tips for basic income - The system allows employers to avoid paying fair wages by shifting the burden to customers

Proposed solutions fall into several categories:

A significant portion of respondents advocate for completely abolishing the tipping system, with employers required to pay workers a living wage instead. Many suggest this would align the U.S. with international standards, particularly European models where tipping is minimal or unnecessary.

Others propose reforming rather than eliminating tipping by: - Making it truly optional and based on service quality - Implementing service charges (around 10%) instead of variable tips - Limiting tipping to traditional full-service situations - Removing pre-service tip requests and aggressive point-of-sale prompts

Those who support tipping emphasize it should reward exceptional service and provide incentive for workers to excel. However, even supporters often acknowledge the system needs boundaries and shouldn't extend to every transaction.

The consensus clearly indicates that while people want service workers to earn fair wages, the current tipping culture has become excessive, creating an unsustainable system that benefits employers at the expense of both workers and customers. Most respondents would prefer a straightforward pricing model where workers receive adequate base pay without depending on customer generosity for survival.
